This is a pretty great tip, actually. I sit in on interviews daily (HR rep), and the best interviews are the ones where the applicant seems genuinely excited to be there. They leave a lasting impression even after they depart the room.
The BEST best applicants are the ones that are so motivated and excited to begin, that they infect the panel members with that motivation also. Remember, the panel themselves are probably bored out of their minds...after listening to people for lengthy amounts of time, that they know shouldn't even be there in the first place. The applicant that can perk the panel members up, can motivate and convince the members how great they'd be in the position....those are the people that get selected 99 times out of 100. ...and I don't mean, just by selling yourself by talking about your great accomplishments. Anyone can do that. True, genuine, enthusiasm. It's hard to fake.

Ahhh, the wonderful fluidity and relativism of the English language.
Yes, a law enforcement officer (LEO) is considered a civilian, compared to a member of the armed forces.
Also yes, a non-LEO citizen is considered a civilian, compared to a member of the LEO community.
So, that being said... Is an LEO a civilian, when compared to a soldier? Yes. Is a citizen a civilian, when compared to an LEO? Yes.

No they aren't.
civilian svilyn/ noun noun: civilian; plural noun: civilians
1. a person not in the armed services or the police force.

I have a Blackvue 650, dual channel (both front and rear cameras). it cost an arm and a leg, but whatever.
I used to use a Mobius action cam mounted forward facing, but I had issues where I noticed that it sometimes failed to turn on when i started the engine, depending on ambient temperature, etc. I switched to the Blackvue so that I would have confidence it would work when I needed it (dash cam is something I want to not think about unless I need it later), so far so good.

The point is...if someone was stealing your credit card, they probably were just going to charge something on it.
BUT, if they see the PIN, they may be tempted to just go get cash from an ATM instead...and get the card locked up from your deliberate honey-pot PIN.

At this point...PIN and ATM have basically become words in and of themselves. Just like how IHOP used to stand for International House of Pancakes....now, it's just IHOP. Like, that's literally the name of the restaurant chain. IHOP.
